Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Studies of Solar Wind - Magnetosphere Interactions using Observations of ULF Waves at an Extensive Ground Array at High Latitudes
Award.AbstractNarration: With this award, researchers from three U.S. institutions will focus on exploring and understanding near-Earth?s space environment (geospace) through the coordinated use of multiple data sets, including both a variety of individual spacecraft and strategically located ground observatories. Because those parts of the Earth?s magnetic field that reach farthest out into geospace intersect the ground at high latitudes, arrays of ground magnetometers and auroral imagers have long been a valued means of monitoring processes in remote parts of the magnetosphere. The ground stations used in this project are key links in arrays of ground-based ionospheric and magnetospheric observations in both the Arctic and Antarctic regions. In conjunction with data from other instruments located at these sites, with other Antarctic arrays of automated instruments, and with both low-altitude and high-altitude satellites, these instruments have played and will continue to play a significant role in the studies of geospace phenomena including solar wind?magnetosphere interactions and geomagnetic storms and substorms. Taken together, search coil instruments at these stations make it possible to study the entire range of ultra-low frequency (ULF) variations, from Pc 1 and Pi 1 pulsations down to Pc 5 pulsations, magnetic impulse events, sudden impulses, and substorm bays, with high sensitivity. The analysis efforts associated with this project will involve, and are highly suitable for, research training of both undergraduate and graduate students, and build on currently strong programs of faculty and student research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award supported ground-based observations of Electromagnetic Ion Cyclotron (EMIC) waves at high-latitudes and analyses of these data. The waves are generated at high altitudes, in Earth's magnetosphere and then propagate to the ionosphere along magnetic field lines. As they reach the ionosphere (at altitudes near 100 km), the resulting plasma interaction couples energy to a signal that can be observed on the ground. This is important because it is what provides the basis for our observations.

The particular class of waves being studied (EMIC) waves is especially important during these times because of their theorized interactions with Earth's radiation belt particles (electrons and protons). With the recent launch of the Van Allen Probe satellites, a widespread communiy effort is focused on understanding the radiation belts; the interactions of waves with energetic particles is an important aspect of that effort.

There are several new contributions that we have published in the peer-reviewed literature from this work. The most interesting, though, is also the most recent result, which consists of a couple surprising and basic results -- especially since these wave have been studied for decades. First, we discovered that the frequencies of the waves themselves depend on the phase of the solar cycle. That is, we found that the waves tend to occur at higher frequencies during intervals of increased solar activity. We believe that this effect is a result of increased numbers of heavy ions in the magnetosphere during these times.

The second surprising result is that we have shown that the transmission of a signal through the ionosphere to the ground depends on sunlight. Specifically, we found that a sunlit ionosphere tends to inhibit observations of waves with frequencies greater than about .5 Hz. To our surprise, this has never been reported until now. While this is important to our study described above because it means that our conclusion underestimates the degree to which frequencies are increased with solar activity, the specific physics of the process that results in this screening is also important. That is, we seek to understand the ionosphere and its interaction with waves in general.

After some thought and discussions with colleagues, we believe we may understand how a sunlit ionosphere can suppress ground signatures of higher frequency waves. The process, we think, involves the absorption of waves power at altitudes well above that where wave energy can provide a signal to the ground. In other words, the waves do not reach the lower ionosphere and no perturbation on the ground can be seen.
